prompt: Facts: Marriage solemnized between Deepika Gupta (Respondent No. 2/Complainant) and Gaurav Gupta on July 13, 2003, in Jaipur.; Appellants are Preeti Gupta (sister-in-law, Nanad) and Pradeep Gupta (brother-in-law, Jeth) of the complainant.; Appellants resided in Mumbai, separate from the complainant and her husband who lived in Ranchi.; Complainant (Deepika Gupta) filed a complaint/FIR No. 247/2008 dated October 10, 2008, at Mahila Police Station, Ranchi.; Allegations in the FIR included demands for dowry, mental and physical torture by the husband (Gaurav Gupta) and his relatives, including the appellants.; The FIR alleged omnibus and general allegations against all named family members without specifying particular roles or incidents involving the appellants.; Police investigated and filed a chargesheet against the husband and his relatives, including the appellants.; Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM), Ranchi, took cognizance of the offences under Sections 498A, 406 IPC, and Sections 3/4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act.; Appellants filed a petition under Section 482 CrPC before the High Court of Jharkhand seeking quashing of the FIR and subsequent criminal proceedings against them.; The High Court dismissed the quashing petition.; Appellants appealed the High Court's decision to the Supreme Court.; Supreme Court observed a growing trend of implicating husband's relatives in matrimonial disputes using general allegations.; Supreme Court noted the appellants lived separately in Mumbai and allegations against them were not specific. | IPC: Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 406 (Punishment for criminal breach of trust), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) - Often invoked implicitly alongside substantive offences like 498A/406 when multiple accused are involved, though not the central focus of the SC's ratio in this specific judgment., Section 3/4 Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 (Mentioned in cognizance order)
